greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the least value of z such that 4/n = 1/x + 1/y + 1/z with 0 < x <= y <= z has at least one solution.
comment: See A073101 and A192787 for the history of the problem, references, and links.
link: Hugo Pfoertner, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000, first 576 terms from Robert Israel.
example: a(6)=6 because it is the least denominator z in the A192787(6)=8 solutions
a(13)=52 because the minimum of z in the A192787(13)=4 solutions is 52:
maple: for x from floor(n*z/(4*z-n))+1 to z do
if y::posint and y >= x and y <= z then return z fi
mathematica: a[n_] := For[z = Floor[n/4] + 1, True, z++, For[x = Floor[n(z/(4z - n))] + 1, x <= z, x++, y = n x z/(4 x z - n x - n z); If[IntegerQ[y] && x <= y <= z, Print[z]; Return [z]]]];
a /@ Range[2, 100] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 23 2020, after _Robert Israel_ *)
results.author: _Hugo Pfoertner_, Oct 13 2020
